Package io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost

Interface InHostMarkovState.InHostMarkovStateMachine

All Superinterfaces:
Serializable
Enclosing interface:
InHostMarkovState
@Immutable public static interface InHostMarkovState.InHostMarkovStateMachine extends Serializable
Defines the transition probabilities for the Markov chain model of disease and symptom progression.

This component encapsulates all time-homogeneous transition rates between states. It enables calibration from epidemiological data (e.g., duration of infectiousness, case fatality rate).

The probability of becoming symptomatic is computed as: \[ p_s = 1 - (1 - r_c)^{1/D} \] where \( r_c \) is the infection-case rate and \( D \) is the average duration of infection, ensuring that over the full infectious period, the cumulative probability of symptoms is \( r_c \).

See Also:
  • getPAsymptomaticSymptomatic()

  • Method Details

    • getPAsymptomaticSymptomatic

      double getPAsymptomaticSymptomatic()
      Returns the daily probability of transitioning from asymptomatic to symptomatic, calibrated to achieve the target infection-case rate over the infectious period.

      If \( r_c \) is the desired case rate and \( D \) is the average duration of infectiousness, then: \[ p_s = 1 - (1 - r_c)^{1/D} \] This ensures that the probability of ever becoming symptomatic during infection is \( r_c \), under the assumption of independent daily risk.

      This formulation assumes each day presents an independent chance of symptom onset, and the overall process resembles a geometric trial or a sum of Bernoulli variables with equal probability — a special case of the Poisson binomial distribution.

      Returns:
      daily probability of symptom onset given infectiousness

    • getPExposedInfectious

      double getPExposedInfectious()
      Returns the daily probability of transitioning from EXPOSED to INFECTIOUS.
      Returns:
      the daily probability of an exposed individual becoming infectious

    • getPHospitalisedAsymptomatic

      double getPHospitalisedAsymptomatic()
      Returns the daily probability of transitioning from HOSPITALISED to ASYMPTOMATIC (recovery), calibrated to achieve the target hospital recovery rate over the course of hospitalisation.
      Returns:
      the daily probability of recovery from hospitalisation, calibrated to match target hospital recovery rates

    • getPHospitalisedDead

      double getPHospitalisedDead()
      Returns the daily probabilities of transitioning from HOSPITALISED to DEAD, and from HOSPITALISED to ASYMPTOMATIC (recovery), calibrated to achieve the target hospital fatality rate (HFR) and recovery rate over the course of hospitalisation.
      Returns:
      the daily probabilities of death and recovery from hospitalisation, calibrated to match target HFR and recovery rates

    • getPImmuneSusceptible

      double getPImmuneSusceptible()
      Returns the daily probability of transitioning from IMMUNE to SUSCEPTIBLE due to waning immunity.
      Returns:
      the daily probability of waning immunity (IMMUNE → SUSCEPTIBLE)

    • getPInfectiousImmune

      double getPInfectiousImmune()
      Returns the daily probability of transitioning from INFECTIOUS to IMMUNE, and from IMMUNE to SUSCEPTIBLE.
      Returns:
      the daily probability of recovery (INFECTIOUS → IMMUNE) and waning immunity (IMMUNE → SUSCEPTIBLE)

    • getPSymptomaticAsymptomatic

      double getPSymptomaticAsymptomatic()
      Returns the daily probabilities of transitions from symptomatic and hospitalised states to less severe or more severe states, calibrated to match population-level outcomes (e.g., IFR, HFR).
      Returns:
      the daily probabilities of symptom progression and regression, including recovery and death, conditioned on current symptom state

    • getPSymptomaticDead

      double getPSymptomaticDead()
      Returns the daily probabilities of transitioning from SYMPTOMATIC to DEAD, and from HOSPITALISED to DEAD, calibrated to achieve the target infection-fatality rate (IFR) and hospital fatality rate (HFR) over the course of the disease.
      Returns:
      the daily probabilities of death from symptomatic and hospitalised states, calibrated to match target IFR and HFR

    • getPSymptomaticHospitalised

      double getPSymptomaticHospitalised()
      Returns the daily probability of transitioning from SYMPTOMATIC to HOSPITALISED, and from SYMPTOMATIC to DEAD.
      Returns:
      the daily probabilities of worsening symptoms leading to hospitalisation or death

    • updateDiseaseState

      default InHostMarkovState.DiseaseState updateDiseaseState(InHostMarkovState.DiseaseState current, Sampler rng)
      Updates the disease state using daily Bernoulli trials.

      Transitions:

      • EXPOSED → INFECTIOUS with probability \( p_{\text{inf}} \),
      • INFECTIOUS → IMMUNE with probability \( p_{\text{rec}} \),
      • IMMUNE → SUSCEPTIBLE with probability \( p_{\text{waning}} \).

      The use of independent Bernoulli draws aligns with the discrete-time survival framework. When aggregating over a population, the number of individuals transitioning follows a Poisson binomial distribution with: \[ \mathbb{E}[N_{\text{transitions}}] = \sum_i p_i, \quad \mathrm{Var}(N_{\text{transitions}}) = \sum_i p_i(1 - p_i) \] as referenced in the knowledge base.

      Parameters:
      current - the current disease state
      rng - the random sampler
      Returns:
      the next disease state

    • updateSymptomState

      default InHostMarkovState.SymptomState updateSymptomState(InHostMarkovState.SymptomState current, InHostMarkovState.DiseaseState dx, Sampler rng)
      Updates the symptom state using multinomial transitions conditioned on disease state.

      For example, from SYMPTOMATIC, the individual may:

      • Recover → ASYMPTOMATIC,
      • Worsen → HOSPITALISED,
      • Deteriorate → DEAD.

      The multinomial draw ensures only one transition occurs per day. The probabilities are calibrated to reproduce population-level outcomes (e.g., IFR) over time.

      Parameters:
      current - the current symptom state
      dx - the current disease state (used to gate symptom onset)
      rng - the random sampler
      Returns:
      the next symptom state
